introduction.p: In section 7.1 we listed some properties of exponential functions without much justification. In this section we will discuss why these properties hold, and investigate the long-run behavior of exponential functions.

subsection.title: Graphs of Exponential Functions
subsection.p: The graphs of exponential functions have two characteristic shapes, depending on whether the base, b, is greater than 1 or less than 1. As typical examples, consider the graphs of f (x) = 2^x and g(x) =\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^x shown in . Some values for f and g are recorded in Tables and .

subsection.p: Notice that f (x) = 2^x is an increasing function and g(x) = \left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^x is a decreasing function. In general, exponential functions have the following properties.

assemblage.title: Properties of Exponential Functions, f(x) = ab^x, a \gt 0

li.p: If b \gt 1, the function is increasing and said to have exponential growthexponential decay;
if 0 \lt b \lt 1, the function is decreasing and said to have exponential decayexponential decay.
The y-intercept is (0, a). There is no x-intercept.

subsection.p: In you can see that as the x-values decrease toward negative infinity, the corresponding y-values decrease toward zero. As a result, the graph of f decreases toward the x-axis as we move to the left. Thus, the x-axis, y=0 , is a horizontal asymptote for exponential functions no matter what value b, the growth factor, happens to be. We can see this illustrated in , since the y-values of each exponential get closer to zero.

For exponential functions with 0 \lt b \lt 1, this takes place close the positive x-axis, as illustrated in b.
For exponential functions with 1 \le b, this takes place close the negative x-axis, as illustrated in a.
In , we compare two increasing exponential functions. The larger the value of the base, b, the faster the function grows. In this example, both functions have a = 1.

statement.p: Compare the graphs of f (x) = 3^x and g(x) = 4^x.

solution.p: We evaluate each function for several convenient values, as shown in .

Plot the points for each function and connect them with smooth curves. For positive x-values, g(x) is always larger than f (x), and is increasing more rapidly. In , g(x) = 4^x climbs more rapidly than f (x) = 3^x. Both graphs cross the y-axis at (0, 1).

sidebyside.p: For decreasing exponential functions, those with bases between 0 and 1, the smaller the base, the more steeply the graph decreases. For example, compare the graphs of p(x) = 0.8^x and q(x) = 0.5^x shown in .
